title: Design Philosophy
text: keyed targets flat-file workflows typically : version control database schema Multiple drifting CSV copies describes data analysis practice: exports systems, shared spreadsheets, periodic dumps. data lives files, tables enforced constraints.

title: Design Philosophy
text: Flat-file workflows rely implicit assumptions: “column unique” “two columns together form key” “shouldn’t NAs ” “join one--one” assumptions live head, scattered comments, nowhere . data changes upstream, assumptions break silently. discover problem downstream—wrong row counts join, duplicated records, missing values expected none.

title: Design Philosophy
text: keyed makes assumptions explicit attaching keys data warning assumptions stop true. core philosophy detection, enforcement: Keys defined validated creation Violations produce warnings, errors (default Checks happen boundaries (joins, exports, commits), every operation Metadata survives transformations possible, degrades gracefully differs database thinking. Databases enforce constraints globally reject invalid states. keyed operates world : Data arrives pre-corrupted Transformations happen outside control R’s copy semantics mean attributes can vanish Session boundaries reset everything Rather fighting , keyed accepts . goal catching problems early, preventing absolutely.

title: Design Philosophy
text: keyed deliberately avoids: Transactions: rollback, atomic operations Version history: branches, diffs time Database semantics: foreign key enforcement, cascading updates Global invariants: system-wide state must stay consistent Required infrastructure: sidecar files, databases, services non-goals, missing features. require infrastructure contradicts flat-file context keyed targets.

title: Design Philosophy
text: Checks run meaningful boundaries: Checks run : mutate(), select(), filter() print() casual inspection Every row access keeps package lightweight. opt validation matters.

title: Design Philosophy
text: Key metadata travels data dplyr operations: operation breaks uniqueness, key dropped warning rather error: reflects reality: sometimes transformations legitimately break keys. keyed tells happens rather blocking operation.
code: library(keyed) library(dplyr) #>  #> Attaching package: 'dplyr' #> The following objects are masked from 'package:stats': #>  #>     filter, lag #> The following objects are masked from 'package:base': #>  #>     intersect, setdiff, setequal, union  df <- data.frame(id = 1:3, x = c("a", "b", "c")) df <- key(df, id)  # Key survives filtering df |> filter(id > 1) |> has_key() #> [1] TRUE  # Key survives mutation df |> mutate(y = toupper(x)) |> has_key() #> [1] TRUE # Creates duplicates - key dropped df |> mutate(id = 1) #> Warning: Key modified and is no longer unique. #> # A tibble: 3 × 2 #>      id x     #>   <dbl> <chr> #> 1     1 a     #> 2     1 b     #> 3     1 c

title: Design Philosophy
text: keyed wrong tool need: keyed fills specific gap: lightweight key tracking exploratory semi-structured workflows heavier tools add friction.

title: Design Philosophy
text: keyed helps : Define keys explicitly key() Check assumptions assume_*() functions Diagnose joins running Track row identity add_id() Detect drift commit_keyed() check_drift() package warns assumptions break. doesn’t enforce correctness provide versioning. constraint intentional—keeps package simple appropriate target context.

title: Quick Start
text: keyed makes key assumptions explicit flat-file data workflows. Define keys , validate creation, let package warn assumptions break. Key features: Define keys key() - single composite columns Keys survive dplyr transformations (filter, mutate, arrange, etc.) Assumption checks assume_unique(), assume_no_na(), etc. Join diagnostics diagnose_join() Optional row IDs lineage tracking add_id() Snapshot-based drift detection commit_keyed() check_drift()

title: Quick Start
code: # install.packages("pak") pak::pak("gcol33/keyed")

title: Quick Start
text: required action defining key:
code: library(keyed) library(dplyr)  # Create sample data users <- data.frame(   user_id = 1:5,   name = c("Alice", "Bob", "Carol", "Dave", "Eve"),   email = c("alice@example.com", "bob@example.com", "carol@example.com",             "dave@example.com", "eve@example.com") )  # Define the key users <- key(users, user_id) users #> # A keyed tibble: 5 x 3 #> # Key:            user_id #>   user_id name  email             #>     <int> <chr> <chr>             #> 1       1 Alice alice@example.com #> 2       2 Bob   bob@example.com   #> 3       3 Carol carol@example.com #> 4       4 Dave  dave@example.com  #> 5       5 Eve   eve@example.com

title: Quick Start
text: key persists dplyr operations: operation breaks uniqueness, key degrades gracefully:
code: # Filter preserves key active <- users |> filter(user_id <= 3) has_key(active) #> [1] TRUE  # Mutate preserves key enriched <- users |> mutate(domain = sub(".*@", "", email)) get_key_cols(enriched) #> [1] "user_id" # This would create duplicates - key is dropped with warning users |> mutate(user_id = 1) #> Warning: Key modified and is no longer unique. #> # A tibble: 5 × 3 #>   user_id name  email             #>     <dbl> <chr> <chr>             #> 1       1 Alice alice@example.com #> 2       1 Bob   bob@example.com   #> 3       1 Carol carol@example.com #> 4       1 Dave  dave@example.com  #> 5       1 Eve   eve@example.com

title: Quick Start
text: Use multiple columns key:
code: orders <- data.frame(   customer_id = c(1, 1, 2, 2),   order_date = c("2024-01-01", "2024-01-02", "2024-01-01", "2024-01-03"),   amount = c(100, 150, 200, 75) )  orders <- key(orders, customer_id, order_date) orders #> # A keyed tibble: 4 x 3 #> # Key:            customer_id, order_date #>   customer_id order_date amount #>         <dbl> <chr>       <dbl> #> 1           1 2024-01-01    100 #> 2           1 2024-01-02    150 #> 3           2 2024-01-01    200 #> 4           2 2024-01-03     75

title: Quick Start
text: Validate assumptions key points workflow:
code: # Check uniqueness assume_unique(users, user_id)  # Check for missing values assume_no_na(users, email)  # Check row count expectations assume_nrow(users, min = 1, max = 100)

title: Quick Start
text: joining, diagnose cardinality:
code: orders <- data.frame(   order_id = 1:6,   user_id = c(1, 1, 2, 3, 3, 3),   amount = c(100, 150, 200, 50, 75, 125) )  diagnose_join(users, orders, by = "user_id")

title: Quick Start
text: lineage tracking, add stable UUIDs rows:
code: # Add IDs users_tracked <- users |> add_id() users_tracked #> # A keyed tibble: 5 x 4 #> # Key:            user_id | .id #>   .id                                  user_id name  email             #>   <chr>                                  <int> <chr> <chr>             #> 1 95a12380-48f9-4911-8d06-06fc4289dab8       1 Alice alice@example.com #> 2 d76f353c-a389-407d-9dfc-84f569a8991f       2 Bob   bob@example.com   #> 3 c78ff452-af48-4062-8e04-44fc40d27235       3 Carol carol@example.com #> 4 6ca05a5d-e9a4-4668-b611-767e9b4b2c19       4 Dave  dave@example.com  #> 5 59a6cfa6-2b78-4a9b-ada4-852f618b74bd       5 Eve   eve@example.com  # Check ID status summary(users_tracked) #>  #> ── Keyed Data Frame Summary #> Dimensions: 5 rows x 4 columns #>  #> Key columns: user_id #> ✔ Key is unique #>  #> Row IDs: present (.id column) #> ✔ 5 unique IDs, no issues

title: Quick Start
text: combining datasets, use bind_id() handle IDs properly:
code: # Existing data with IDs batch1 <- add_id(data.frame(x = 1:3))  # New data without IDs batch2 <- data.frame(x = 4:6)  # Combine - checks for overlaps and fills missing IDs combined <- bind_id(batch1, batch2) combined #>                                    .id x #> 1 55926c8e-9795-4842-ae45-21153736ebd9 1 #> 2 8eb39eba-3087-4d60-8a23-a3eaadfff18c 2 #> 3 d889d9b9-c9c8-4cfc-9024-f8f2046a7e18 3 #> 4 ef303a00-7ffa-4dbe-9dee-2e340c60ee78 4 #> 5 8d6a7777-c1c2-42a4-bc02-caab63031fd5 5 #> 6 13e50c5b-82c9-4373-8edd-623ea3eedf21 6

title: Quick Start
text: Create deterministic IDs column values:
code: sales <- data.frame(   country = c("US", "UK", "US"),   year = c(2023, 2023, 2024),   revenue = c(1000, 800, 1200) )  sales <- make_id(sales, country, year) sales #>       .id country year revenue #> 1 US|2023      US 2023    1000 #> 2 UK|2023      UK 2023     800 #> 3 US|2024      US 2024    1200

title: Quick Start
text: Track changes time snapshots:
code: # Commit a snapshot users <- commit_keyed(users) #> ✔ Snapshot committed: c2930fbe...  # Later, check for drift check_drift(users) #>  #> ── Drift Report #> ✔ No drift detected #> Snapshot: c2930fbe... (2026-01-14 11:32)  # Clean up clear_all_snapshots() #> ! This will remove 1 snapshot(s) from cache. #> ✔ Cleared 1 snapshot(s).

what: keyed: Explicit Key Assumptions for Flat-File Workflows
title: keyed: Explicit Key Assumptions for Flat-File Workflows
text: Explicit Key Assumptions Flat-File Data Workflows keyed package helps define maintain key assumptions data workflows work CSVs, Excel files, flat files without database schemas. Define keys , validate creation, get warnings assumptions break.

title: keyed: Explicit Key Assumptions for Flat-File Workflows
code: library(keyed) library(dplyr)  # Define a key - the only required action users <- read.csv("users.csv") |>   key(user_id)  # Keys survive transformations active_users <- users |>   filter(status == "active") |>   mutate(domain = sub(".*@", "", email))  has_key(active_users) #> [1] TRUE  # Check assumptions assume_unique(users, user_id) assume_no_na(users, email)  # Diagnose joins before running them diagnose_join(users, orders, by = "user_id") #> ── Join Diagnosis ── #> Cardinality: one-to-many #> x: 1000 rows, unique #> y: 5432 rows, 4432 duplicates

title: keyed: Explicit Key Assumptions for Flat-File Workflows
text: Working flat files (CSVs, Excel exports) often means implicit assumptions data structure: “column unique”, “columns form composite key”, “shouldn’t NAs ”. assumptions live head scattered comments, breaking silently data changes. keyed addresses providing: Explicit key definitions travel data transformations Graceful degradation - warnings keys break, hard failures Assumption checks boundaries (imports, exports, joins) rather every operation Optional lineage tracking stable row IDs Drift detection catch changes data versions

title: keyed: Explicit Key Assumptions for Flat-File Workflows
code: # install.packages("pak") pak::pak("gcol33/keyed")

title: keyed: Explicit Key Assumptions for Flat-File Workflows
code: # Single key users <- key(data, user_id)  # Composite key orders <- key(data, customer_id, order_date)  # Check key status has_key(users) get_key_cols(users) key_is_valid(users)

title: keyed: Explicit Key Assumptions for Flat-File Workflows
code: # Uniqueness assume_unique(data, col1, col2)  # Missing values assume_no_na(data, required_col)  # Completeness (all expected values present) assume_complete(data, category, expected = c("A", "B", "C"))  # Coverage (reference values covered) assume_coverage(data, id, reference = ref_data$id)  # Row count assume_nrow(data, min = 100, max = 10000)

title: keyed: Explicit Key Assumptions for Flat-File Workflows
code: # Analyze join before executing diagnose_join(users, orders, by = "user_id") #> ── Join Diagnosis ── #> Cardinality: one-to-many #> x: 1000 rows, unique #> y: 5432 rows, 4432 duplicates  # For validated joins, use joinspy # pak::pak("gcol33/joinspy")

title: keyed: Explicit Key Assumptions for Flat-File Workflows
text: Opt-stable UUIDs lineage tracking:
code: # Add IDs to rows users <- add_id(users)  # IDs persist through transformations filtered <- users |> filter(active) get_id(filtered)  # Same IDs as original rows  # Combine data with ID handling combined <- bind_id(batch1, batch2)  # Checks overlaps, fills missing  # Create deterministic IDs from columns sales <- make_id(data, country, year)  # "US|2024"  # Validate ID integrity check_id(data) check_id_disjoint(data1, data2)  # Compare before/after compare_ids(before, after) #> $lost: 2 IDs #> $gained: 5 IDs #> $preserved: 998 IDs

title: keyed: Explicit Key Assumptions for Flat-File Workflows
code: # Commit a reference snapshot users <- commit_keyed(users) #> ✓ Snapshot committed: a5ab1a98...  # Later, check for changes check_drift(users) #> ── Drift Report ── #> ⚠ Drift detected #> ℹ Row count: 1000 -> 1024 (+24) #> ℹ Cell values modified

title: keyed: Explicit Key Assumptions for Flat-File Workflows
code: # Quick status check key_status(users) summary(users)  # Compare keys between datasets compare_keys(old_data, new_data)  # Find duplicates find_duplicates(data, key_col)

title: keyed: Explicit Key Assumptions for Flat-File Workflows
text: Keys explicit: Define , validate creation Warnings errors: Alert violations, don’t block default Graceful degradation: Key metadata survives transformations possible, drops cleanly Boundary checks: Validate joins exports, every operation magic: hidden state, sidecar files, databases

title: keyed: Explicit Key Assumptions for Flat-File Workflows
text: Install joinspy richer join diagnostics:
code: pak::pak("gcol33/joinspy")  # diagnose_join() automatically uses joinspy when available diagnose_join(users, orders, by = "user_id") #> ── Pre-Join Diagnostic Report ── #> ... detailed whitespace, encoding, and match analysis ...

title: Add identity column — add_id
text: Adds stable UUID column row. opt-feature tracking row lineage transformations.

title: Add identity column — add_id
code: add_id(.data, .id = ".id", .overwrite = FALSE)

title: Add identity column — add_id
text: .data data frame. .id Column name ID (default: ".id"). .overwrite TRUE, overwrite existing ID column. FALSE (default), error column exists.

title: Add identity column — add_id
text: Data frame ID column added.

title: Add identity column — add_id
text: IDs generated using hash row content plus random salt, making stable identical rows within session unique across different data frames. uuid package available, used true UUIDs. Otherwise, hash-based ID generated.

title: Add identity column — add_id
code: df <- data.frame(x = 1:3, y = c("a", "b", "c")) df <- add_id(df) df

what: Assert that data is complete (no missing values anywhere) — assume_complete
title: Assert that data is complete (no missing values anywhere) — assume_complete
text: Checks columns NA values.

title: Assert that data is complete (no missing values anywhere) — assume_complete
code: assume_complete(.data, .strict = FALSE)

title: Assert that data is complete (no missing values anywhere) — assume_complete
text: .data data frame. .strict TRUE, error failure. FALSE (default), warn.

title: Assert that data is complete (no missing values anywhere) — assume_complete
text: Invisibly returns .data (piping).

what: Assert minimum coverage of values — assume_coverage
title: Assert minimum coverage of values — assume_coverage
text: Checks fraction non-NA values meets threshold. Useful joins verify expected coverage.

title: Assert minimum coverage of values — assume_coverage
code: assume_coverage(.data, threshold, ..., .strict = FALSE)

title: Assert minimum coverage of values — assume_coverage
text: .data data frame. threshold Minimum fraction non-NA values (0 1). ... Column names (unquoted) check. empty, checks columns. .strict TRUE, error failure. FALSE (default), warn.

title: Assert minimum coverage of values — assume_coverage
text: Invisibly returns .data (piping).

title: Assert minimum coverage of values — assume_coverage
code: df <- data.frame(id = 1:10, x = c(1:8, NA, NA)) assume_coverage(df, 0.8, x) assume_coverage(df, 0.9, x)  # warns (only 80% coverage)

what: Assert that columns have no missing values — assume_no_na
title: Assert that columns have no missing values — assume_no_na
text: Checks specified columns contain NA values.

title: Assert that columns have no missing values — assume_no_na
code: assume_no_na(.data, ..., .strict = FALSE)

title: Assert that columns have no missing values — assume_no_na
text: .data data frame. ... Column names (unquoted) check. empty, checks columns. .strict TRUE, error failure. FALSE (default), warn.

title: Assert that columns have no missing values — assume_no_na
text: Invisibly returns .data (piping).

title: Assert that columns have no missing values — assume_no_na
code: df <- data.frame(id = 1:3, x = c("a", NA, "c")) assume_no_na(df, id) assume_no_na(df, x)  # warns

what: Assert row count within expected range — assume_nrow
title: Assert row count within expected range — assume_nrow
text: Checks number rows within expected range. Useful sanity checks filtering joins.

title: Assert row count within expected range — assume_nrow
code: assume_nrow(.data, min = 1, max = Inf, expected = NULL, .strict = FALSE)

title: Assert row count within expected range — assume_nrow
text: .data data frame. min Minimum expected rows (inclusive). Default 1. max Maximum expected rows (inclusive). Default Inf. expected Exact expected row count. provided, overrides min/max. .strict TRUE, error failure. FALSE (default), warn.

title: Assert row count within expected range — assume_nrow
text: Invisibly returns .data (piping).

title: Assert row count within expected range — assume_nrow
code: df <- data.frame(id = 1:100) assume_nrow(df, min = 50, max = 200) assume_nrow(df, expected = 100)

what: Assert that columns are unique — assume_unique
title: Assert that columns are unique — assume_unique
text: Checks combination specified columns unique values. point--time assertion either passes silently fails.

title: Assert that columns are unique — assume_unique
code: assume_unique(.data, ..., .strict = FALSE)

title: Assert that columns are unique — assume_unique
text: .data data frame. ... Column names (unquoted) check uniqueness. .strict TRUE, error failure. FALSE (default), warn.

title: Assert that columns are unique — assume_unique
text: Invisibly returns .data (piping).

title: Assert that columns are unique — assume_unique
code: df <- data.frame(id = 1:3, x = c("a", "b", "c")) assume_unique(df, id)  # Fails with warning df2 <- data.frame(id = c(1, 1, 2), x = c("a", "b", "c")) assume_unique(df2, id)

what: Bind data frames with ID handling — bind_id
title: Bind data frames with ID handling — bind_id
text: Binds data frames properly handling ID columns. Checks overlapping IDs, combines data, fills missing IDs.

title: Bind data frames with ID handling — bind_id
code: bind_id(..., .id = ".id")

title: Bind data frames with ID handling — bind_id
text: ... Data frames bind. .id Column name IDs (default: ".id").

title: Bind data frames with ID handling — bind_id
text: Combined data frame valid IDs rows.

title: Bind data frames with ID handling — bind_id
text: function: Checks IDs overlap datasets (warns ) Binds rows using dplyr::bind_rows() Fills missing IDs using extend_id() Use instead dplyr::bind_rows() working ID columns.

title: Bind data frames with ID handling — bind_id
code: df1 <- add_id(data.frame(x = 1:3)) df2 <- data.frame(x = 4:6) combined <- bind_id(df1, df2)

what: Bind rows of keyed data frames — bind_keyed
title: Bind rows of keyed data frames — bind_keyed
text: Bind keyed data frames

title: Bind rows of keyed data frames — bind_keyed
code: bind_keyed(..., .id = NULL)

title: Bind rows of keyed data frames — bind_keyed
text: ... Data frames bind. .id Optional column name identify source.

title: Bind rows of keyed data frames — bind_keyed
text: keyed data frame key preserved unique, otherwise tibble.

title: Bind rows of keyed data frames — bind_keyed
text: Wrapper dplyr::bind_rows() attempts preserve key metadata.

what: Bind rows of keyed data frames — bind_rows_keyed
title: Bind rows of keyed data frames — bind_rows_keyed
text: Wrapper dplyr::bind_rows attempts preserve key.

title: Bind rows of keyed data frames — bind_rows_keyed
code: bind_rows_keyed(..., .id = NULL)

title: Bind rows of keyed data frames — bind_rows_keyed
text: ... Data frames bind. .id Optional column name identify source.

title: Bind rows of keyed data frames — bind_rows_keyed
text: keyed data frame key preserved unique, otherwise tibble.

what: Check for drift from committed snapshot — check_drift
title: Check for drift from committed snapshot — check_drift
text: Compares current data committed reference snapshot. Returns diagnostic information changes.

title: Check for drift from committed snapshot — check_drift
code: check_drift(.data, reference = NULL)

title: Check for drift from committed snapshot — check_drift
text: .data data frame snapshot reference. reference Optional content hash compare . NULL, uses attached snapshot reference.

title: Check for drift from committed snapshot — check_drift
text: drift report (class keyed_drift_report), NULL snapshot found.

title: Check for drift from committed snapshot — check_drift
code: df <- key(data.frame(id = 1:3, x = c("a", "b", "c")), id) df <- commit_keyed(df)  # Modify the data df$x[1] <- "modified" check_drift(df)

title: Check ID integrity — check_id
text: Validates ID column common issues: missing values, duplicates, suspicious formats.

title: Check ID integrity — check_id
code: check_id(.data, .id = ".id")

title: Check ID integrity — check_id
text: .data data frame ID column. .id Column name (default: ".id").

title: Check ID integrity — check_id
text: Invisibly returns list : valid: TRUE issues found n_na: count NA values n_duplicates: count duplicate IDs format_ok: TRUE IDs look like proper UUIDs/hashes

title: Check ID integrity — check_id
code: df <- add_id(data.frame(x = 1:3)) check_id(df)

what: Check IDs are disjoint across datasets — check_id_disjoint
title: Check IDs are disjoint across datasets — check_id_disjoint
text: Verifies ID columns overlap datasets. Useful binding datasets ensure ID collisions.

title: Check IDs are disjoint across datasets — check_id_disjoint
code: check_id_disjoint(..., .id = ".id")

title: Check IDs are disjoint across datasets — check_id_disjoint
text: ... Data frames check. .id Column name IDs (default: ".id").

title: Check IDs are disjoint across datasets — check_id_disjoint
text: Invisibly returns list : disjoint: TRUE overlaps found overlaps: character vector overlapping IDs ()

title: Check IDs are disjoint across datasets — check_id_disjoint
code: df1 <- add_id(data.frame(x = 1:3)) df2 <- add_id(data.frame(x = 4:6)) check_id_disjoint(df1, df2)

what: Clear all snapshots from cache — clear_all_snapshots
title: Clear all snapshots from cache — clear_all_snapshots
text: Clear snapshots cache

title: Clear all snapshots from cache — clear_all_snapshots
code: clear_all_snapshots(confirm = TRUE)

title: Clear all snapshots from cache — clear_all_snapshots
text: confirm TRUE, require confirmation.

what: Clear snapshot for a data frame — clear_snapshot
title: Clear snapshot for a data frame — clear_snapshot
text: Removes snapshot reference data frame.

title: Clear snapshot for a data frame — clear_snapshot
code: clear_snapshot(.data, purge = FALSE)

title: Clear snapshot for a data frame — clear_snapshot
text: .data data frame. purge TRUE, also remove snapshot cache.

title: Clear snapshot for a data frame — clear_snapshot
text: Data frame without snapshot reference.

what: Commit a keyed data frame as reference — commit_keyed
title: Commit a keyed data frame as reference — commit_keyed
text: Stores hash-based snapshot current data state. one active reference per data frame (identified content hash).

title: Commit a keyed data frame as reference — commit_keyed
code: commit_keyed(.data, name = NULL)

title: Commit a keyed data frame as reference — commit_keyed
text: .data data frame (preferably keyed). name Optional name snapshot. NULL, derived data.

title: Commit a keyed data frame as reference — commit_keyed
text: Invisibly returns .data snapshot metadata attached.

title: Commit a keyed data frame as reference — commit_keyed
text: snapshot stores: Row count Column names types Hash key columns (keyed) Hash full content Snapshots stored memory session. keyed content hash, identical data shares snapshot.

title: Commit a keyed data frame as reference — commit_keyed
code: df <- key(data.frame(id = 1:3, x = c("a", "b", "c")), id) df <- commit_keyed(df)  # Later, check for drift df2 <- df df2$x[1] <- "z" check_drift(df2)

what: Compare IDs between data frames — compare_ids
title: Compare IDs between data frames — compare_ids
text: Compares IDs two data frames detect lost rows.

title: Compare IDs between data frames — compare_ids
code: compare_ids(before, after, .id = ".id")

title: Compare IDs between data frames — compare_ids
text: Data frame transformation. Data frame transformation. .id Column name IDs (default: ".id").

title: Compare IDs between data frames — compare_ids
text: list : lost: IDs present gained: IDs present preserved: IDs present

title: Compare IDs between data frames — compare_ids
code: df1 <- add_id(data.frame(x = 1:5)) df2 <- df1[1:3, ] compare_ids(df1, df2)

what: Compare key values between two data frames — compare_keys
title: Compare key values between two data frames — compare_keys
text: Identifies keys new, removed, common two keyed data frames. compare values, key membership.

title: Compare key values between two data frames — compare_keys
code: compare_keys(x, y, by = NULL)

title: Compare key values between two data frames — compare_keys
text: x First keyed data frame. y Second keyed data frame. Column(s) compare. NULL, uses key x.

title: Compare key values between two data frames — compare_keys
text: key comparison object.

title: Compare key values between two data frames — compare_keys
code: df1 <- key(data.frame(id = 1:3, x = 1:3), id) df2 <- key(data.frame(id = 2:4, x = 2:4), id) compare_keys(df1, df2)

what: Compare structure of two data frames — compare_structure
title: Compare structure of two data frames — compare_structure
text: Compares structural properties two data frames without comparing actual values. Useful detecting schema drift.

title: Compare structure of two data frames — compare_structure
code: compare_structure(x, y)

title: Compare structure of two data frames — compare_structure
text: x First data frame. y Second data frame.

title: Compare structure of two data frames — compare_structure
text: structure comparison object.

title: Compare structure of two data frames — compare_structure
code: df1 <- data.frame(id = 1:3, x = c("a", "b", "c")) df2 <- data.frame(id = 1:5, x = c("a", "b", "c", "d", "e"), y = 1:5) compare_structure(df1, df2)

what: Diagnose a join before executing — diagnose_join
title: Diagnose a join before executing — diagnose_join
text: Analyzes join cardinality without performing full join. Useful detecting many--many joins explode row count.

title: Diagnose a join before executing — diagnose_join
code: diagnose_join(x, y, by = NULL, use_joinspy = TRUE)

title: Diagnose a join before executing — diagnose_join
text: x Left data frame. y Right data frame. Join specification. use_joinspy TRUE (default), use joinspy enhanced diagnostics available. Set FALSE use built-diagnostics .

title: Diagnose a join before executing — diagnose_join
text: list cardinality information, JoinReport object joinspy used.

title: Diagnose a join before executing — diagnose_join
text: joinspy package installed, function delegates joinspy::join_spy() enhanced diagnostics including whitespace detection, encoding issues, detailed match analysis.

title: Diagnose a join before executing — diagnose_join
code: x <- data.frame(id = c(1, 1, 2), a = 1:3) y <- data.frame(id = c(1, 1, 2), b = 4:6) diagnose_join(x, y, by = "id", use_joinspy = FALSE)

what: Extend IDs to new rows — extend_id
title: Extend IDs to new rows — extend_id
text: Adds IDs rows ID column NA, preserving existing IDs. Useful binding new data existing dataset IDs.

title: Extend IDs to new rows — extend_id
code: extend_id(.data, .id = ".id")

title: Extend IDs to new rows — extend_id
text: .data data frame ID column (possibly NAs). .id Column name IDs (default: ".id").

title: Extend IDs to new rows — extend_id
text: Data frame IDs filled NA rows.

title: Extend IDs to new rows — extend_id
code: # Original data with IDs old <- add_id(data.frame(x = 1:3))  # New data without IDs new <- data.frame(.id = NA_character_, x = 4:5)  # Combine and extend combined <- dplyr::bind_rows(old, new) extend_id(combined)

title: Find duplicate keys — find_duplicates
text: Identifies rows duplicate key values.

title: Find duplicate keys — find_duplicates
code: find_duplicates(.data, ...)

title: Find duplicate keys — find_duplicates
text: .data data frame. ... Column names check. empty, uses key columns.

title: Find duplicate keys — find_duplicates
text: Data frame containing rows duplicate keys, .n column showing count.

title: Find duplicate keys — find_duplicates
code: df <- data.frame(id = c(1, 1, 2, 3, 3, 3), x = letters[1:6]) find_duplicates(df, id)

title: Get ID column — get_id
text: Get ID column

title: Get ID column — get_id
code: get_id(.data, .id = ".id")

title: Get ID column — get_id
text: .data data frame. .id Column name (default: ".id").

title: Get ID column — get_id
text: Character vector IDs, NULL present.

text: Get key column names

title: Get key column names — get_key_cols
code: get_key_cols(.data)

title: Get key column names — get_key_cols
text: .data keyed data frame.

title: Get key column names — get_key_cols
text: Character vector column names, NULL key.

what: Check if data frame has IDs — has_id
title: Check if data frame has IDs — has_id
text: Check data frame IDs

title: Check if data frame has IDs — has_id
code: has_id(.data, .id = ".id")

title: Check if data frame has IDs — has_id
text: .data data frame. .id Column name check (default: ".id").

title: Check if data frame has IDs — has_id
text: Logical.

what: Check if data frame has a key — has_key
title: Check if data frame has a key — has_key
text: Check data frame key

title: Check if data frame has a key — has_key
code: has_key(.data)

title: Check if data frame has a key — has_key
text: .data data frame.

title: Check if data frame has a key — has_key
text: Logical.

what: Define a key for a data frame — key
title: Define a key for a data frame — key
text: Attaches key metadata data frame, marking column(s) form unique identifier rows. Keys validated uniqueness creation.

title: Define a key for a data frame — key
code: key(.data, ..., .validate = TRUE, .strict = FALSE)  key(.data) <- value

title: Define a key for a data frame — key
text: .data data frame tibble. ... Column names (unquoted) form key. Can single column multiple columns composite key. .validate TRUE (default), check key unique. .strict TRUE, error non-unique keys. FALSE (default), warn still attach key. value Character vector column names use key.

title: Define a key for a data frame — key
text: keyed data frame (class keyed_df).

title: Define a key for a data frame — key
code: df <- data.frame(id = 1:3, x = c("a", "b", "c")) key(df, id)  # Composite key df2 <- data.frame(country = c("US", "US", "UK"), year = c(2020, 2021, 2020), val = 1:3) key(df2, country, year)

what: keyed: Explicit Key Assumptions for Flat-File Data — keyed-package
title: keyed: Explicit Key Assumptions for Flat-File Data — keyed-package
text: Helps R users make implicit data assumptions explicit attaching keys flat-file data warning assumptions violated. Designed CSV-first workflows without databases, schemas, version control. Provides key definition, assumption checks, join diagnostics, optional drift detection reference snapshots.

title: keyed: Explicit Key Assumptions for Flat-File Data — keyed-package
text: Maintainer: Gilles Colling gillescolling@gmail.com

what: Check if the key is still valid — key_is_valid
title: Check if the key is still valid — key_is_valid
text: Checks whether key columns still exist still unique.

title: Check if the key is still valid — key_is_valid
code: key_is_valid(.data)

title: Check if the key is still valid — key_is_valid
text: .data keyed data frame.

title: Check if the key is still valid — key_is_valid
text: Logical. Returns FALSE warning key invalid.

title: Get key status summary — key_status
text: Returns diagnostic information keyed data frame.

title: Get key status summary — key_status
code: key_status(.data)

title: Get key status summary — key_status
text: .data data frame.

title: Get key status summary — key_status
text: key status object diagnostic information.

title: Get key status summary — key_status
code: df <- key(data.frame(id = 1:3, x = c("a", "b", "c")), id) key_status(df)

what: List all snapshots in cache — list_snapshots

title: List all snapshots in cache — list_snapshots

title: Create ID from columns — make_id
text: Creates ID column combining values one columns. Unlike add_id(), produces deterministic IDs based column values.

title: Create ID from columns — make_id
code: make_id(.data, ..., .id = ".id", .sep = "|")

title: Create ID from columns — make_id
text: .data data frame. ... Columns combine ID. .id Column name ID (default: ".id"). .sep Separator column values (default: "|").

title: Create ID from columns — make_id
text: Data frame ID column added.

title: Create ID from columns — make_id
code: df <- data.frame(country = c("US", "UK", "US"), year = c(2020, 2020, 2021)) make_id(df, country, year) #>   .id       country year #> 1 US|2020  US      2020 #> 2 UK|2020  UK      2020 #> 3 US|2021  US      2021

title: keyed 0.1.0
text: key() / unkey(): Define remove keys data frames has_key() / get_key_cols() / key_is_valid(): Query key status Keys survive dplyr transformations (filter, mutate, arrange, etc.) Graceful degradation warnings key uniqueness breaks

title: keyed 0.1.0
text: assume_unique(): Verify column uniqueness assume_no_na(): Check missing values assume_complete(): Ensure expected values present assume_coverage(): Validate reference coverage assume_nrow(): Check row count bounds

title: keyed 0.1.0
text: diagnose_join(): Analyze join cardinality executing Optional integration joinspy enhanced diagnostics

title: keyed 0.1.0
text: add_id() / remove_id(): Add/remove stable UUIDs has_id() / get_id(): Query ID status extend_id(): Fill missing IDs binding make_id(): Create composite IDs columns bind_id(): Combine data ID handling check_id() / check_id_disjoint(): Validate ID integrity compare_ids(): Detect lost/gained rows

title: keyed 0.1.0
text: commit_keyed(): Commit reference snapshot check_drift(): Detect changes snapshot list_snapshots() / clear_snapshot() / clear_all_snapshots(): Manage snapshots

title: keyed 0.1.0
text: key_status(): Quick status summary summary.keyed_df(): Detailed summary method compare_structure(): Compare schema data frames compare_keys(): Compare key values datasets find_duplicates(): Locate duplicate key values
